trans-unit.source: title: Step 8: Experiment with Windows PowerShell
trans-unit.target: title: Step 8: Experiment with Windows PowerShell

trans-unit.source: Step 8: Experiment with Windows PowerShell
trans-unit.target: Step 8: Experiment with Windows PowerShell

trans-unit.source: Test update to see if new XLIF contains everything.
trans-unit.target: Test update to see if new XLIF contains everything.

trans-unit.source: Now that you have walked through the basics of deploying Hyper-V, creating virtual machines and managing these virtual machines, let’s explore how you can automate many of these activities with PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: Now that you have walked through the basics of deploying Hyper-V, creating virtual machines and managing these virtual machines, let’s explore how you can automate many of these activities with PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: Return a list of Hyper-V commands
trans-unit.target: Return a list of Hyper-V commands

trans-unit.source: Click on the Windows start button, type PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: Click on the Windows start button, type PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: Run the following command to display a searchable list of PowerShell commands available with the Hyper-V PowerShell Module.
trans-unit.target: Run the following command to display a searchable list of PowerShell commands available with the Hyper-V PowerShell Module.

trans-unit.source: You get something like this:
trans-unit.target: You get something like this:

trans-unit.source: To learn more about a particular PowerShell command use get-help.
trans-unit.target: To learn more about a particular PowerShell command use get-help.

trans-unit.source: For instance running the following command will return information about the get-vm Hyper-V command.
trans-unit.target: For instance running the following command will return information about the get-vm Hyper-V command.

trans-unit.source: The output shows you how to structure the command, what the required and optional parameters are, and the aliases that you can use.
trans-unit.target: The output shows you how to structure the command, what the required and optional parameters are, and the aliases that you can use.

trans-unit.source: Return a list of virtual machines
trans-unit.target: Return a list of virtual machines

trans-unit.source: Use the get-vm command to return a list of virtual machines.
trans-unit.target: Use the get-vm command to return a list of virtual machines.

trans-unit.source: In PowerShell, run the following command:
trans-unit.target: In PowerShell, run the following command:

trans-unit.source: This displays something like this:
trans-unit.target: This displays something like this:

trans-unit.source: To return a list of only powered on virtual machines add a filter to the get-vm command.
trans-unit.target: To return a list of only powered on virtual machines add a filter to the get-vm command.

trans-unit.source: A filter can be added by using the where-object command.
trans-unit.target: A filter can be added by using the where-object command.

trans-unit.source: For more information on filtering see the <link><linkText>Using the Where-Object</linkText><title></title></link> documentation.
trans-unit.target: For more information on filtering see the <link><linkText>Using the Where-Object</linkText><title></title></link> documentation.

trans-unit.source: To list all virtual machines in a powered off state, run the following command.
trans-unit.target: To list all virtual machines in a powered off state, run the following command.

trans-unit.source: This command is a copy of the command from step 2 with the filter changed from ‘Running’ to ‘Off’.
trans-unit.target: This command is a copy of the command from step 2 with the filter changed from ‘Running’ to ‘Off’.

trans-unit.source: Start and shut down virtual machines
trans-unit.target: Start and shut down virtual machines

trans-unit.source: To start a particular virtual machine, run the following command with name of the virtual machine:
trans-unit.target: To start a particular virtual machine, run the following command with name of the virtual machine:

trans-unit.source: To start all currently powered off virtual machines, get a list of those machines and pipe the list to the 'start-vm' command:
trans-unit.target: To start all currently powered off virtual machines, get a list of those machines and pipe the list to the 'start-vm' command:

trans-unit.source: To shut down all running virtual machines, run this:
trans-unit.target: To shut down all running virtual machines, run this:

trans-unit.source: Create a VM checkpoint
trans-unit.target: Create a VM checkpoint

trans-unit.source: To create a checkpoint using PowerShell, select the virtual machine using the get-vm command and pipe this to the checkpoint-vm command.
trans-unit.target: To create a checkpoint using PowerShell, select the virtual machine using the get-vm command and pipe this to the checkpoint-vm command.

trans-unit.source: Finally give the checkpoint a name using -snapshotname.
trans-unit.target: Finally give the checkpoint a name using -snapshotname.

trans-unit.source: The complete command will look like the following:
trans-unit.target: The complete command will look like the following:

trans-unit.source: For example, here is a checkpoint with the name DEMOCP:
trans-unit.target: For example, here is a checkpoint with the name DEMOCP:

trans-unit.source: Create a new virtual machine
trans-unit.target: Create a new virtual machine

trans-unit.source: The following example shows how to create a new virtual machine in the PowerShell Integrated Scripting Environment (ISE).
trans-unit.target: The following example shows how to create a new virtual machine in the PowerShell Integrated Scripting Environment (ISE).

trans-unit.source: This is a simple example and could be expanded on to include additional PowerShell features and more advanced VM deployments.
trans-unit.target: This is a simple example and could be expanded on to include additional PowerShell features and more advanced VM deployments.

trans-unit.source: To open the PowerShell ISE click on start, type PowerShell ISE.
trans-unit.target: To open the PowerShell ISE click on start, type PowerShell ISE.

trans-unit.source: Run the following code to create a virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: Run the following code to create a virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: See the <link><linkText>New-VM</linkText><title></title></link> documentation for detailed information on the New-VM command.
trans-unit.target: See the <link><linkText>New-VM</linkText><title></title></link> documentation for detailed information on the New-VM command.

trans-unit.source: Wrap up and References
trans-unit.target: Wrap up and References

trans-unit.source: This document has shown some simple steps to explorer the Hyper-V PowerShell module as well as some sample scenarios.
trans-unit.target: This document has shown some simple steps to explorer the Hyper-V PowerShell module as well as some sample scenarios.

trans-unit.source: For more information on the Hyper-V PowerShell module, see the <link><linkText>Hyper-V Cmdlets in Windows PowerShell reference</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information on the Hyper-V PowerShell module, see the <link><linkText>Hyper-V Cmdlets in Windows PowerShell reference</linkText><title></title></link>.
